title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not indicate that an ecological community refers to all of the interacting populations in a defined habitat. (Additional information: Of particular interest in describing the structure of a community is the species diversity, all of the different species present, and the species composition, the total number of organisms of each species.)

The response indicates that an ecological community refers to all of the interacting populations in a defined habitat. (Additional information: Of particular interest in describing the structure of a community is the species diversity, all of the different species present, and the species composition, the total number of organisms of each species.)

title: Part B (ii)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not indicate that medium-sized animals are the leopards’ most common prey. It also does not indicate that based on error bars, large and very large animals are equally likely to be the lions’ most common prey.

The response indicates that medium-sized animals are the leopards’ most common prey. It also indicates that based on error bars, large and very large animals are equally likely to be the lions’ most common prey.

title: Part C (i)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not indicate that there are fluctuations, but overall the leopard population size appears to have been unaffected by the lion population size. (Additional information: At different time points, only one of the two populations increased or decreased in size, and at other time points, they both increased or decreased in size. Therefore the best conclusion is that the two population sizes changed independently of each other.)

The response indicates that there are fluctuations, but overall the leopard population size appears to have been unaffected by the lion population size. (Additional information: At different time points, only one of the two populations increased or decreased in size, and at other time points, they both increased or decreased in size. Therefore the best conclusion is that the two population sizes changed independently of each other.)

title: Part D (i)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not indicate that 38% of the prey animals of the lions make up 63% of the consumed biomass, so if the availability of the very large animals becomes limiting, the leopards and lions will start to compete for prey (and this will be especially true of the medium-sized prey).

The response indicates that 38% of the prey animals of the lions make up 63% of the consumed biomass, so if the availability of the very large animals becomes limiting, the leopards and lions will start to compete for prey (and this will be especially true of the medium-sized prey).

title: Part D (ii)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not indicate that for the most part, the leopards and lions rely on prey animals of different size and so do not compete for food. (The population data suggest that their population sizes have remained fairly constant over time, also suggesting that they are not in direct competition.)

The response indicates that for the most part, the leopards and lions rely on prey animals of different size and so do not compete for food. (The population data suggest that their population sizes have remained fairly constant over time, also suggesting that they are not in direct competition.)
